entry.title: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order: Plant-to-Plant A2A Orchestration
entry.content:
Use-case: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order (Plant-to-Plant A2A scenario driven by real-time APIs)

A fast-moving material in Plant A is kept in stock by an end-to-end, automated flow that

  1. checks forecast demand,
  2. looks for internal surplus in nearby plants, and
  3. automatically creates stock transfers or purchase requisitions as needed.

Prerequisities and needed

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Inventory & MRP) – On-hand stock, stock in transit, MRP items
  • SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) – Demand forecast for FG-100 at Plant A
  • SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) – Real-time on-hand stock incl. quarantine
  • SAP Ariba – Supplier catalog and pricing for external options
  • External supplier catalog (Ariba-like) – External pricing and lead times
  • SAP Integration Suite / SAP Event Mesh – Orchestrates the end-to-end flow and publishes events

Sequence – how the APIs interact end-to-end

Step 0 – Trigger
A nightly iFlow in SAP Integration Suite (or SAP Event Mesh) starts the orchestration.

Step 1 – Demand forecast
GET /api/ibp/v1/demandplanning/forecast?material=FG-100&plant=A&weeks=4
→ Returns 1,200 pcs forecasted demand.

Step 2 – Current & projected stock in Plant A
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=A
→ 180 pcs unrestricted, 40 pcs blocked.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems?material=FG-100&plant=A
Result: confirmed receipts 600 pcs
→ Confirmed receipts 600 pcs, so net shortage = 1,200 – 180 – 600 = 420 pcs.

Step 3 – Locate surplus stock in the network
Parallel calls (one per plant):
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=B
→ 300 pcs unrestricted.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=C
→ 250 pcs unrestricted.

Step 4 – Check ATP (available-to-transfer) incl. transit time
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability
Body:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"plant": "B", 
"demandQty": 300, 
"requiredDate": "2024-06-25" 
}

→ Confirms 300 pcs can be delivered by 2024-06-23.
Same for Plant C → 120 pcs available by 2024-06-24.

Step 5 – Decide cheapest internal option
Cost service (custom REST on S/4):
POST /internal/transferCost

{ 
"fromPlants": ["B","C"], 
"toPlant": "A", 
"qty": [300,120] 
}


→ Plant B has the lowest freight cost (€0.05/pc vs €0.07/pc).

Step 6 – Create stock transport order (STO)
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder
Body:

{ 
"SupplyingPlant": "B", 
"ReceivingPlant": "A", 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"OrderQuantity": 300, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-23" 
}

→ STO 4500012345 created.

Step 7 – Remaining uncovered quantity
Shortage after internal transfer = 420 – 300 = 120 pcs.
Call Ariba to get best external price:
GET /v2/suppliers/catalog?material=FG-100&qty=120&currency=EUR
→ Supplier S-987 offers €2.30/pc, lead time 7 days.

Step 8 – Create purchase requisition in S/4
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader
Body:

{ 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"Plant": "A", 
"Quantity": 120, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-27", 
"SupplierHint": "S-987" 
}

→ PR 1000123456 created.

Step 9 – Notify planners
Publish event to SAP Event Mesh topic /business/plantA/stockReplenished
Payload:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"sto": "4500012345", 
"pr": "1000123456", 
"status": "covered" 
}

Outcome
Plant A will receive 300 pcs from Plant B via an automatically created STO and 120 pcs via a purchase requisition with the cheapest external supplier—no manual intervention, no stock-out, and minimal freight cost.

complete code

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
End-to-end A2A flow:
1. Read demand forecast (IBP)
2. Check stock & MRP in Plant A
3. Search surplus stock in Plants B/C
4. Run ATP check
5. Create STO (cheapest internal)
6. Create PR for remaining qty (Ariba best price)
"""

import os, json, math
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from requests import Session
from requests_oauthlib import OAuth2Session
from oauthlib.oauth2 import BackendApplicationClient

load_dotenv()

# ---------- CONFIG ----------
MATERIAL = "FG-100"
PLANT_A  = "A"
PLANTS_SURPLUS = ["B", "C"]
DEMAND_WEEKS   = 4
TRANSPORT_DAYS = 2
# ----------------------------

s = Session()

# ---------- 0.  OAUTH TOKEN for S/4 ----------
def s4_token():
    url = f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/oauth/token"
    r = s.post(url,
               auth=(os.getenv('S4_USER'), os.getenv('S4_PASSWORD')),
               data={'grant_type':'client_credentials'})
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['access_token']

s.headers.update({'Authorization': f"Bearer {s4_token()}"})

# ---------- 1.  IBP – demand forecast ----------
def ibp_forecast():
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_DEMAND_PLANNING_SRV/DemandForecast")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{PLANT_A}'",
        "$select": "DemandQuantity",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    total = sum(item['DemandQuantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])
    return total

demand_qty = ibp_forecast()
print("Demand forecast:", demand_qty)

# ---------- 2.  Stock & MRP ----------
def plant_stock(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"StorageLocation ne ''",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['UnrestrictedStockQuantity']
               for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

def plant_receipts(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"MrpElementCategory eq 'AR'",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['Quantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

stock_A = plant_stock(PLANT_A)
receipts_A = plant_receipts(PLANT_A)
shortage = max(0, demand_qty - stock_A - receipts_A)
print("Shortage:", shortage)
if shortage == 0:
    print("No action needed.")
    exit()

# ---------- 3.  Surplus stock ----------
surplus = {}
for p in PLANTS_SURPLUS:
    surplus[p] = plant_stock(p)
print("Surplus:", surplus)

# ---------- 4.  ATP check ----------
def atp_ok(plant, qty, req_date):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": plant,
        "DemandQuantity": str(qty),
        "RequiredDate": req_date.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['d']['ConfirmedQuantity'] == str(qty)

best_internal = None
needed = shortage
for plant, qty in surplus.items():
    take = min(qty, needed)
    req = datetime.utcnow().date() + timedelta(days=TRANSPORT_DAYS)
    if atp_ok(plant, take, req):
        best_internal = (plant, take)
        break
if best_internal:
    plant, qty = best_internal
    print(f"Best internal: {qty} from {plant}")

    # ---------- 5.  Create STO ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder")
    body = {
        "SupplyingPlant": plant,
        "ReceivingPlant": PLANT_A,
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "OrderQuantity": str(qty),
        "DeliveryDate": req.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    sto = r.json()['d']['StockTransportOrder']
    print("STO created:", sto)
    shortage -= qty

# ---------- 6.  Ariba – best external price ----------
if shortage > 0:
    client = BackendApplicationClient(client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'))
    oauth = OAuth2Session(client=client)
    token = oauth.fetch_token(
        token_url=os.getenv('ARIBA_TOKEN_URL'),
        client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'),
        client_secret=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_SECRET')
    )
    url = "https://api.ariba.com/v2/suppliers/catalog"
    params = {
        "material": MATERIAL,
        "qty": shortage,
        "currency": "EUR"
    }
    r = oauth.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    best = min(r.json()['offers'], key=lambda x: float(x['price']))
    print("Best supplier:", best['supplier'], best['price'])

    # ---------- 7.  Create PR ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": PLANT_A,
        "Quantity": str(shortage),
        "DeliveryDate": (datetime.utcnow().date()
                         + timedelta(days=int(best['leadtime']))).isoformat(),
        "SupplierHint": best['supplier']
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    pr = r.json()['d']['PurchaseRequisition']
    print("PR created:", pr)

print("Flow finished.")

entry.title: Combine Revenue Contracts to solve IFRS15 / ASC 606 Bundle scenarios (Multi-Element Arrangements)
entry.content:
As already presented by Volkmar Zahn, since SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408 release, it is possible to activate Universal Revenue Recognition (URR) for specific stock selling scenarios, service contracts and fixed-price customer projects. Subscription billing was also added as an additional URR scenario as part of the 2502.02 release.

This blog is not about re-explaining Universal Revenue Recognition as this was very well done in Volkmar’s blog.

Introduction to Universal Revenue Recognition - SAP Community

What I present here is a solution option that leverages the use of the Solution Order to sell bundles combining products and services and using URR to be compliant with the IFRS15 and ASC606 requirements of allocating the transaction price to the different performance obligations applying the stand-alone selling price basis.

The solution uses the existing Business Add-In (BAdI) BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items (FARR_BADI_ENRICH_ORDER_ITEM) that allows combining revenue accounting contracts that are created from different operational documents, such as customer projects, sales orders, service contracts or subscription billing items.

Contract Combination in Universal Revenue Recognition | SAP Help Portal

There’s no need to implement this BAdI if your operational document is only a Sales order as Revenue contracts are combined automatically for Sales orders with the same customer reference.

Example

A company that sells subscription products and consulting altogether offers a bundle to a customer where the products are priced with uneven discount (so contractual individual price is different from the stand-alone selling price) as follows.

Figure 1 - Customer Order details

Solution Order Creation

To reflect this customer order in the system, a Solution order is created with five Subscription Billing items and one Professional Service Project item.

Figure 2 - Solution Order

For each solution order item, contractual price and stand-alone selling price is informed at item level. See price calculation detail for item 10.

Figure 3 - Solution Order Item detail

As the bundle meets the IFRS 15 / ASC 606 criteria to be consider a combination of contracts, you need to implement the Business Add-In (BAdI) BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items (FARR_BADI_ENRICH_ORDER_ITEM), otherwise each line item will create a single contract with a single performance obligation (POB).  

How to implement the BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items

Business Role Prerequisites

Business role Extensibility Specialist (SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).

Step 1

Go to the App Custom Logic and click Create.

Figure 4 - Custom Logic App

Step 2

Search for Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items.

Figure 5 - Custom Logic App New Implementation

Step 3

Select the node, and there will be the button step 2. Give any text to description and give an implantation ID, such as YY1_COMBINE_PER_SOLUTION_ORDER.

And you can click review.

Figure 6 - Custom Logic App Implementation ID

Step 4

In the last step click Create, at the bottom.

Figure 7 - Custom Logic App Create

Step 5

Then click the publish in the next screen.

Figure 8 - Custom Logic App Publish

Step 6

Click the edit button.

Figure 9 - Custom Logic App Edit

Step 7

Enter the edit mode.

 

Figure 10 - Custom Logic App Edit Mode

And code the logic following the directions from the BADI help:

Assign the same value to the reference type (REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFTYPE) and to the reference ID (REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFERENCE) of the order items that you would like to combine.

Contract Combination in Universal Revenue Recognition | SAP Help Portal

Once your code is finish, click the publish button to complete the BADI implementation.

Results you should obtain

In our solution order example the BADI logic assigns the following values:

REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFTYPE : SOL (as origin is a Solution Order)

REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFERENCE : 0100000120 (the solution order number)

When creating the Revenue Accounting Item from the Provider Contracts of the Subscription Billing items, all items from the same solution order will have the same values in these two fields and will be automatically combined.

Checking the results of the BADI implementation

You can use App Manage Revenue Accounting Items to check the content of the Reference Type and Reference ID that the BADI has populated. Filter Item Type (Order Item) and the creation date or other parameters that helps you identify your Revenue Accounting Items.

Figure 11 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items

You see in the list all the Subscription Billing Items from our Solution order have the same values in Reference Type and Reference ID.

Now let’s check the Revenue Contract created. Click on the Revenue Contract Icon and the Revenue Contract Number and Performance Obligation are displayed for each accounting principle you have activated.

Figure 12 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items (Check Revenue Contract)

Figure 13 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items (Check Revenue Contract)

We can see Revenue Contract for different line items is the same, while Performance Obligation is not, hence the Revenue Contract is combined.

Checking the Revenue Contract

From any of the Revenue Accounting Items you can navigate to the Revenue Contract. Alternatively you can also use the app Manage Revenue Contracts and inform the number.

Figure 14 - Manage Revenue Accounting Item (Navigate to Revenue Contract)

The Revenue Contract is displayed with all combined items that have the same solution order number, showing the contractual value, the stand-alone selling price and the allocated amount and allocated effect.

Figure 15 - Manage Revenue Contract App

The allocated amount is calculated proportionally to the stand-alone selling price and will be the base for the individual revenue recognition of each item.

Price Allocation | SAP Help Portal

Standalone Selling Price-Weighted Allocation | SAP Help Portal

Combining the Project Item

When including a Professional Service Project Item to a Solution Order you have the option to automatically create the Project ID. The Project ID created is the combination of the Solution order ID and item ID. You can see the project created in app Plan Customer Projects.

Figure 16 - Plan Customer Projects App (Header)

The project planning must be done, as the solution order only creates the project ID. When planning the billing, all you must do to combine the project with the subscription items is to inform the solution order reference in the customer reference field as you see below. Pay attention to include the initial zero, before the number, same as it shows in the Revenue Accounting Item for the Subscription Billing items.

Figure 17 - Plan Customer Project App (Billing)

The customer reference of the project is copied to the project sales order header.

Figure 18 - Display Sales Order App (Header)

As it meets the standard criteria (Sales orders with the same customer reference are combined with the same revenue contracts),it’s combined automatically into the same Revenue Contract as we have seen previously (see POB 6216 in Revenue Contract 718, corresponding to sales order 105).

Figure 19 - Manage Revenue Contract App

End-to-End Process Orchestration

This Figure shows all the relevant objects and process orchestration for this solution

Figure 20 - Process Orchestration

 

Stay tuned to URR future enhancements.

As mentioned by Volkmar Zahn in Introduction to Universal Revenue Recognition - SAP Community 

this is just the beginning and URR capabilities will be growing steadily over time.

See the S/4Hana Public Cloud Revenue Recognition Help for further details

Universal Revenue Recognition:   SAP Help URR

Event-Based Revenue Recognition: SAP Help EBRR

Contract-Based Revenue Recognition: SAP Help CBRR

entry.title: Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud

In order to understand the organogram of any organization, it is essential to learn the functions of every org unit. Just like in a family, some people play the roles of guardians, supervisors and some are only dependents on elder, likewise SAP org units are. 
Every organization utilizes its resources to earn profits so from where can we extract the profitability reports? It means there is a unit made responsible to collect information, analyse and report it in every manner that is "CO-PA". (Controlling- Profitability Segment). So, Operating Concern is like a super power who sits on the top of the org structure and have all the information. In SAP Public Cloud one operating concern is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other.   It is assigned to controlling area, where all variable and fixed costs of the company is stored. Just like there cannot remain two swords in one sheath, similarly two controlling areas cannot be created. In SAP Public Cloud one controlling area is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other. 

The world of Finance begin when companies start trading, hence just like we have multiple universes, multiple company codes are assigned to controlling areas. Company code is the smallest org structure in FI that stores all financial documents line items. It becomes a base for MM and SD structure, an independent family member upon which other gets dependent. Company codes nomenclature can be alpha-numeric. FI Consultant will begin the org structure creation activity in SAP Public Cloud. Lets take one scenario as an example. lets say a group of companies will be made as a company and its subsidiaries will be configured as separate company codes. 

Plant is the area which is responsible to record every production activity. What is happening inside a plant, cannot be known to that person who is sitting on the head of the family chair on the dining table. (CO-PA). Therefore, MM Consultant configures the alphanumeric plants to the company codes and with this relation, correct information passes to controlling area and reports of profit gets extracted. Profit is made of Revenue-Costs, so costs are available with controlling area, but what about revenue? 

So we have another stream, another module i,e SD who is solely responsible to dispatch and record sales. Then like a river, it flows into the sea of Finance and gets connected to CO-PA. 

MM and SD are two extreme opposite sides, SD is a plus and MM is minus. (Inflows and outflows) MM has its own purchasing org, that can either be centralized or decentralized as per company's policies. 
Similarly, SD has its own sales org,  SD consultant can assign one on multiple company codes or create a decentralized structure. 

In connection to controlling area. CO consultant designs a hierarchy of cost centers and profit centers to record their activities. Purchases can be found in multiple cost centers, and via report it can be plan to control it. Whereas, sales can be assigned profitability segments to know their contributions in profit figures. 

Under plant, multiple storage locations for inventory can be configured and assigned and under the same plant, sales area is made. Sales area is the combination of sales org, divisions and distribution channel. The longest activity in org structure is of SD module.  

The material is either procured externally or produced in-house, it moves from plant to warehouse, then stamped in sales office, it dispatches from shipping points to final consumer and consumer happily transfers the receipt in company's bank account. That's how production is materialized into finance. 

Please note no consultant can begin configuration without completing the organisational structure. 

It can be edited and recreated later on. but it will lock your workspace for sometime. After doing changes, confirm the units and deploy it onto your configuration server. 

Reports are formulated with the help of transactions, if a purchase order is made in MM, check the org units, (plant, purchasing org and storage location)  will be filled, so automatically it will be assigned to its respective company code and would reach CO-PA. SD will also follow the same in its preliminary financial documents. Hence, create a strong structure to uphold the data in correct formats and form. 

Till now, we have CO-FI-MM and SD in the picture and that's how organisational structure is framed in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud. The role of CO is predefined, in Grey cannot be changed in any circumstances.

entry.title: New fields available for Mexico electronic invoices
entry.content:
Hello, everybody 

Let’s dive into the latest updates regarding the additional tags for complemento in electronic invoice XMLs, as allowed by Mexican government authorities. These tags are categorized as follows: 

  • Complemento for the complemento tag 
  • Complementoconcepto for the concepto tag 
     

Our localization team has developed two new Business Add-Ins (BAdIs), which are set to be delivered in the upcoming release for S/4HANA Public Cloud. These enhancements allow you to dynamically create tags, as allowed by the government. 
 
The new BAdIs are: 

  • Mexico: Extending Fields for Complemento Header Node (EDOC_MX_FILL_COMPLEMENTO_HEADR): extend fields for the Complemento node in the XML or PDF for electronic documents. 
  • Mexico: Extending Fields for Complemento Concepto Node (EDOC_MX_FILL_COMPLMNT_CONCEPTO): extend fields for the Complemento Concepto node in the XML or PDF file for electronic documents. 

 

To implement new complementos for Conceptos, such as ventavehiculos or instEducativas you need to use the BAdI EDOC_MX_FILL_COMPLMNT_CONCEPTO. Additionally, it is necessary to perform some steps in iFlow, regardless of whether you are using the standard or a custom version. 

 

Configuring the iFlow: 

  1. In Integration flow select: Runtime Configuration -> Namespace Mapping

       1.1 Add the Namespace Mapping: "ventavehiculos( ;xmlns:ventavehiculos=http://www.sat.gob.mx/ventavehiculos )", as below: 
 

ventavehiculos( ;xmlns:ventavehiculos=http://www.sat.gob.mx/ventavehiculos )

To state the obvious: Getting your taxes right is an important part of your business, and it’s not an area where you’d typically seek out additional complexities.

This is the shortest possible version of why it’s difficult to change your sales and use tax procedure in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Your tax procedure is something you set up in your initial scoping, and it is in most cases the deepest asleep of all of your sleeping dogs. Almost all the time, you just want to leave it alone.

Almost. There are times when you need to make a change. Perhaps your business structure has changed sufficiently that you want to move from the internal tax calculation procedure to the external and join up with a tax partner. Or maybe you need to switch tax partners.

In these cases, with live systems, you need to think carefully, plan for disruption, think again, and plan some more. And then probably do that one more time. Then if you’re going ahead, consult our KBA entitled Information on the Internal Tax Calculation Procedure (TAXUSJ) to the External Tax Calculation Procedure (0TXUSX) for more detailed information on the procedure, risks, and potential downtimes associated with such a switch.

entry.title: Smarter Quality Management with AI-Assisted Processing - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Managing incoming quality certificates has long been a time-consuming, error-prone process. Manual uploads, mismatched documents, and delays in inspection can create bottlenecks that impact production timelines and even revenue.

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, SAP introduces a game-changing enhancement: AI-assisted processing of quality certificates with SAP Document AI.

This new capability brings automation, accuracy, and intelligence to a critical step in the quality management process.

Why This Matters

Traditionally, quality technicians spend hours uploading, checking, and confirming certificates from suppliers. Even small errors or missing documents can block stock usage decisions, leading to costly delays.

SAP Document AI changes the game by:

  • Automatically extracting data from certificates in multiple formats (PDF, scanned docs, images).
  • Matching certificates to existing receipts using built-in logic.
  • Attaching the document and updating the status automatically.
  • Freeing quality teams to focus on inspections instead of paperwork.

How It Works

The process is seamless:

1. Upload: Certificates are uploaded in the Upload Quality Certificate Documents app.

2. Extract: SAP Document AI extracts key data (PO number, material, supplier).

3. Match: The system checks extracted data against existing certificate receipts.

4. Confirm: If a match is found, the receipt status updates to Received and the document is attached.

5. Automate: New or updated receipts are flagged with automation levels (Created Automatically / Changed Automatically).

Automation Level is set to “Created Automatically” when a new certificate receipt is created. For existing certificate receipt Automation level is set to “Changed Automatically”.

6. Review (Optional): If data is incomplete, quality technicians can manually review and retry matching.

Review the data extracted from the document, such as the purchase order, supplier, or material and the corresponding data in your system that SAP Document AI identified as a match for the extracted data.

   6.1 Manual Review: Extracted data is incomplete or not entirely accurate 
If the system cannot clearly identify or update the certificate receipt (for example, the original paper document may be damaged, or its format may not allow a full extraction), you can review the extracted data and manually complete the matching process.

Manually resolve inconclusive cases in the Review Certificate Document Matches app where you can review and correct the details. When you choose Retry Matching, the system uses this updated data to again find a certificate receipt for the document.

Benefits at a Glance

  • Reduce the time required to process incoming certificates and thereby free up time for quality technicians to focus on their core tasks.
  • Reduce manual efforts and thus process costs.
  • Increase quality mechanisms: No certificates are lost or overlooked.
  • Minimize errors due to incorrectly assigned objects.

Real-World Example

Imagine a supplier delivers raw materials, but the certificate confirmation is missing. Traditionally, production waits until the quality technician manually uploads and verifies the document. With SAP Document AI, the system automatically:

  • Reads the certificate.
  • Matches it to the supplier’s delivery.
  • Updates the inspection lot.
  • Unlocks the material for usage decision.

The Future of Intelligent Quality Management

This enhancement marks a shift from reactive document handling to intelligent, proactive quality assurance. By embedding AI into routine certificate processing, SAP helps organizations:

  • Improve productivity.
  • Reduce risk of human error.
  • Build a foundation for fully automated quality management.

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, companies now have a smarter, faster way to ensure product quality and compliance — powered by SAP Document AI.

Further reading:
SAP Document AI — The Roadmap for Seamless Document Processing in SAP Business Suite

entry.title: How to perform a successful Carve-Out in SAP ECC and S/4HANA – Update and New Trends 2025 (Part I)
entry.content:
It has been four years since I published my original five-part series on SAP Carve-Outs - covering basic topics from what a carve out is (Part I), data migration (Part II) and technical orchestration (Part III) to process and analytics considerations (Part IV) and S/4HANA value creation (Part V).

Time for a look back on what has changed since then with new trends for SAP Carve-Outs and Divestiture Projects in business and technology.

The good news is: The core principles and methods outlined in those earlier posts remain as relevant today as they were then.

However, the past four years have brought notable shifts in both business dynamics and technology landscapes, reshaping how carve-out projects must be planned, managed, and executed. In many cases, these changes have introduced greater complexity, requiring organizations to adapt their strategies to ensure success.

From our recent project experience and industry observations, two main drivers stand out:

  1. More complex M&A scenarios – including multi-entity, multi-source, and joint-venture carve-outs, often with heightened compliance and harmonization requirements.
  2. Technology disruption – particularly the accelerated move to the cloud and the looming SAP ECC end-of-maintenance deadlines (2027, or 2030 with costly extended maintenance under SAP RISE).

In this update, I will explore these emerging trends from two perspectives:

Business & M&A Scenario-Driven Trends (Part I):

  • Harmonization of processes and structures during the carve-out to reduce operational complexity post-transition.
  • Multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs that combine data from different systems into a consolidated environment.
  • Enhanced compliance and legal alignment to address stricter regulatory and contractual requirements.
  • Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go-live to keep operations running seamlessly and without any business disruption

Technology-Driven Trends (Part II):

  • Move to cloud – whether via hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) in private hosting, or through SAP RISE and GROW with SAP offerings.
  • Expanded functional and integration scope – including SAP modules, third-party systems (Salesforce, Ariba, IBP, EDI), and rebuilt analytics landscapes.
  • Combined carve-out and S/4HANA transformation to deliver a modern, value-enhanced system to the buyer.
  • Custom code carve-out and clean-core modernization to simplify future operations and reduce technical debt.

Both parts of this post build on the foundation of the original series, now enriched with current project examples and the latest industry best practices - offering a forward-looking view of what it takes to execute a successful carve-out in 2025 and beyond.

 

Business and M&A Scenario–Driven Trends in Modern SAP Carve-Outs

1. Harmonization of Processes and Structures

In recent years, we have seen a growing emphasis on harmonizing processes and organizational structures during carve-outs – especially to reduce operational complexity after the transition. This is particularly common among private equity buyers, who aim to simplify process variants, adopt industry best practices over heavy customization, and standardize reporting structures across multiple acquisitions. Two main approaches are used:

Option 1: Greenfield Implementation in the Public Cloud

Some buyers opt for a brand-new SAP system - often in an SAP GROW public cloud environment - built entirely on standardized, industry best-practice processes.

  • Advantages: Fast to implement, provides a clean slate, and allows extensions via SAP BTP without burdening the core system.
  • Caveats:
    • Historic data is typically lost, requiring separate archival for audit or business purposes.
    • The “big bang” cutover into entirely new processes can disrupt business operations without strong change management.

This approach is best suited for asset deals or acquisitions of smaller, less complex entities.

Option 2: Selective Data Transition (SDT)

With the right Transformation Software, SDT enables you to migrate only selected data while simultaneously transforming processes, configurations, and structures. For example, in a carve-out involving multiple company codes from a highly integrated environment, intercompany relationships may need to be converted into customer-vendor-structures - requiring both process reconfiguration and master/transactional data transformation.

SDT also allows:

  • Changing charts of accounts, profit/cost centers, plants, and org structures.
  • Transforming open and historical transactional data to match new processes.
  • Maintaining a continuity of historical data in the new environment.

Trade-offs: SDT is more complex, typically requiring 6-12 months for high-complexity projects and demanding greater involvement from both IT and business teams.

We have seen SDT increasingly used in share deals, spin-offs, and large-scale asset divestitures with significant process complexity.

 

2. Multi-Source & Joint-Venture Carve-Outs

Another fast-growing trend involves multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs, where data from multiple ERP systems must be consolidated into one new environment.

Typical scenarios:

  • Multi-source carve-out: Extracting data from several ERP systems (ECC, S/4HANA, or both) within the same organization, often during ongoing SAP S/4HANA transformation projects.
  • Joint-venture setup: Merging data and processes from multiple partners into a shared system.

Challenges include:

  • Harmonizing master data, processes, charts of accounts, and org structures – including historic transactional data.
  • Managing licensing and data visibility between different corporate owners.
  • Separating and rebuilding formerly shared subsystems or third-party integrations.

Given their complexity, these projects nearly always use SDT combined with system merge methodologies, cross-system harmonization, and automation for plant or unit reallocation - while ensuring strict data access controls between Joint-Venture partners.

Additionally, these projects require a significant engagement from SAP specialists to adjust and reshape processes, harmonize data and organizaional structures, properly adjust interfaces to external or cloud-based systems, and enhance data analytics and reporting. Due to the variety of skill sets needed and the urgency in a carve-out project, the setup usually requires engaging with a specialized System Integrator (SI) early in the project planning phase to ensure these topics are successfully covered.

 

3. Enhanced Compliance & Legal Alignment

Stricter regulations and geopolitical constraints now significantly influence carve-out planning and execution.

Examples include:

  • GDPR for companies doing business in EU-countries
  • Industry-specific requirements (e.g., regulated industries like Utilities, Aerospace & Defense).
  • Data sovereignty laws such as China’s DSL, CSL, and PIPL, which can require a separate, localized SAP system, to protect your global business data by keeping it separate.

Implications:

  • Migrate only approved data subsets, particularly personal data.
  • Ensure full audit documentation of extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Include technical safeguards such as log tracing, reversible deletions, and cutover checks.

Modern SDT Software products - like cbs ET Enterprise Transformer - already offer audit-grade logging for these processes, making compliance easier to prove post-project.

 

Vendor landscape Note:

In the context of the SDT approach, it is worth noting that only four vendors worldwide currently provide both the specialized SDT software and the associated service capabilities needed for complex carve-out scenarios. All are members of the SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement Program and typically collaborate with other system integrators (SI) to cover the full range of services required.

At present, only one of these vendors is able to deliver the complete end-to-end service portfolio independently - an advantage that means fewer communication gaps, with consultants who understand the full scope of services and the role of SDT in the project, rather than working in isolated silos.

Given the sustained market demand for SDT-based initiatives - including both carve-outs and broader SAP S/4HANA transformation projects - delivery capacity can become a bottleneck. To mitigate this risk, organizations should secure delivery slots as early as possible, ideally before the transaction is finalized and the Transition Services Agreement (TSA) is signed, to ensure the resource availability and alignment with agreed project timelines.

 

4. Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go/live

A successful carve-out is not just about getting the technical cutover right - it’s equally about ensuring the carved-out organization can operate smoothly from day one. One of the most significant risks during these projects is operational disruption, which both buyer and seller are highly motivated to avoid before, during, and after the system handover. Maintaining stable business operations has increasingly become therefore a central project goal.

Change Management and Training

Beyond ensuring clean, accurate data in the new system, it is critical to prepare the business workforce for changes to their daily processes and routines. This requires structured change management and targeted training in all areas where processes are being redesigned or where new roles and responsibilities are introduced. This becomes even more important when moving to more standardized, harmonized processes - often with fewer customization and a leaner user interface than in the previous environment.

In such cases, acceptance grows when users understand the why behind the change and are given the tools and guidance to confidently perform their work in the new system. Proper preparation minimizes post–go-live disruption and supports long-term adoption.

Application Management Services (AMS)

In recent years, we have seen a strong trend toward integrating AMS into carve-out project scope from the outset. This is particularly relevant when:

  • The carved-out entity lacks internal SAP expertise after organizational changes or downsizing post-transaction.
  • The seller’s IT services under the TSA come at a premium, and the buyer seeks a faster, more cost-effective transition away from them.
  • The buyer needs a bridging solution until a new internal IT team is in place.

Some AMS providers even offer fractional consulting for small-scale enhancements and process improvements after go-live, adding flexibility during the stabilization phase.

Choosing a provider who delivers AMS as part of a comprehensive business transformation has clear advantages, as they understand carve-out–specific requirements such as altered team responsibilities, new support structures, and heightened service continuity needs.

For smaller and mid-sized organizations, SAP’s M&A Ambassador Program can be a valuable option, particularly for PE-driven carve-outs. It equips these projects with expert partner frameworks to manage both the initial deployment and post-go-live stabilization. Unfortunately, this program does not include any provider with SDT capabilities.

Recommendation: Define AMS scope and contracts early - including infrastructure operations, interface monitoring, patching, SLA targets, and knowledge handover - so that post-go-live operations run as smoothly as the cutover itself.

 

Summary of Part I and Key Takeaways

Over the past years, my team and I have seen, and experienced with our customers, that carve-outs in 2025 are no longer purely IT-driven exercises.They are strategic business transformations requiring early leadership engagement and precise planning.

On the business side, the key success factors are:

  • Early preparation: Business readiness and TSA alignment before signing prevent costly delays.
  • Selective Data Transition (SDT) as a game changer: Enabling selective migration and process harmonization with minimal disruption; early partner selection is crucial given limited global capacity.
  • Integrated service delivery: One provider delivering end-to-end reduces communication gaps and ensures holistic understanding.
  • Business continuity protection: Early investment in process mapping, change management, and training ensures smoother cutovers.
  • Built-in stabilization: Integrating AMS from the onset speeds post–go-live recovery.
  • Organizational change management: Early engagement drives faster adoption and productivity.

For the technical delivery models, toolsets, and SDT-related innovations shaping carve-outs in 2025 and beyond, see Part II of this Update 2025 post.

If you’d like to discuss your own carve-out scenario, feel free to contact me directly. @Lorenz_Praefcke2

entry.title: Financing with Taulia: Dynamic Discounting with Credit Memos
entry.content:
Starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508, the dynamic discounting scenario in Payables Financing supports posting discounts via credit memos.

Dynamic discounting is a financial strategy that allows suppliers to receive early payments from buyers by offering discounts on invoices. Previously, the dynamic discounting process only supported the Invoice Adjustment discount type, which offers the discount directly against the original invoice amount. Now, a new discount type, Discount by Credit Memo, has been introduced. When a discount is considered a rebate, it can now be posted with a credit memo in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system on a date agreed upon by the supplier and buyer. This ensures businesses accurately report deductions in trade payables and value-added tax (VAT) liabilities to tax authorities.

Process Flow

  1. The buyer posts supplier invoices in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  2. The supplier takes the early payment offer on the Taulia Platform and requests an early payment for selected invoices.
  3. The early payment request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Based on the early payment request, a payables financing order is created automatically with the Discount by Credit Memo discount type. Upon the creation of the financing order, a credit memo is also created and posted for the discount.

    In the Display Payables Financing Orders app, the credit memo and the leading invoice are included as line items of the financing order and the credit memo is linked to the leading invoice via an invoice reference. The details of the credit memo are replicated to the Taulia Platform.

  4. The buyer pays the supplier on the agreed early payment date.
  5. The supplier gets an early payment from the buyer.
Note

The buyer can raise a ticket on the Taulia Platform to cancel an early payment request. Once canceled, the status of the payables financing order updates to Canceled in the Display Payables Financing Orders app. At the same time, the system automatically reverses and clears the credit memo, updating its clearing status to Cleared Item and generating a clearing journal entry.

Examples of the User Interface

Note

The screenshots are examples to make the described change visible. Please note that the screenshots show the English version of the user interface only, and that the user interface in your system might look slightly different due to configuration and extensibility options available.

The following screenshot shows how it looks in the system when a credit memo is created and posted for a discount:

Implementation Details

Configuration

To enable the new discount type of dynamic discounting, ensure relevant settings are made in the following configuration activities in your configuration environment:

  • Define Company Codes for Receivable Items/Payable Items (ID: 106901)

  • Define Number Range Intervals for Payables Financing Orders (ID: 106893)

  • Automatic Account Determination (ID: 100297)

    In this activity, proceed as follows to define a dedicated G/L account for posting dynamic discounts:
    1. In the Area section, maintain the fields as below:
      • Area: Financial Accounting
      • Subarea: Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable
      • Process: Define Accounts for Payment Transactions
    2. In the Parameters section, maintain the fields as below:
      • Transaction Group: SKN (Cash Discount and Payment Differences)
      • Transaction Key: SKD (Dynamic Discount for Payables Financing)
      • Chart of Accounts: Enter a chart of accounts.
    3. In the Account Assignments section, specify a G/L account for debit postings.
    Note

    The system also supports posting discounts via credit memos for invoices related to fixed asset acquisitions. To do this, ensure that a G/L account is assigned as a technical clearing account for integrated asset acquisitions in the Assign G/L Accounts (ID: 102622) configuration activity.

    Note

    If the leading invoice contains CO account assignment objects (for example, cost center), the credit memo is also posted with the same account assignment objects. If not, make sure the dedicated G/L account for posting dynamic discounts has CO account assignment objects defined in the Manage Default Account Assignments (ID: 102639) configuration activity.

entry.title: View/Access backend data in S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition
entry.content:
As a SAP Consultant many of us are currently in a phase where we are migrating from an “On-Premise” working mindset to a “Cloud” way of working . One of the very common questions that comes to our mind when we start work on S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition is how can we view or access backend data. In an On-Premise environment we are habituated to do this using transaction code SE16N and also SE11, if it is to view backend structure. In S/4 HANA Cloud,Private Edition you can still see the table level data using traditional approach by using SE16N Tcode as you still have the SAP GUI available, but when it comes to S/4 HANA Cloud, Public Edition we do not get to see data directly through tables as we used to do in a On-Premise environment. Here we use CDS views for the purpose.

This mini blog post demonstrates how to check backend data in S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition as compared to traditional approach of using SE16N

Here in this context we will discuss about two Fiori applications–

  1. View Browser
    Role needed - SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST
    Catalogs - SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_AQA_PC

  2. Customer Data Browser
    Role Needed - SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR_DANA
    Catalog - SAP_CORE_BC_CDB_PC

View Browser -

You use this app to view the structure of the CDS views and two other important information “Key User Release state” and “Cloud Development release state”

Lets take the example of the CDS view for Product master data - I_PRODUCT     

When you open I_PRODUCT from this application as shown in the image, it shows you the data types and also the underlying tables and other views that are used for association.

The backend referenced tables can be seen from the tab “Cross Reference”

Customer Data Browser –

With this app you get to see the actual backend data. Here also we take the reference of standard CDS view - I_PRODUCT.

The basic landing page of the app looks like the one in below image. There are two tabs one for “Tables” and one for “CDS Views”. We only have access to the tab “CDS Views”

You can switch between technical names and functional names of the fields

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
With the 2508 release, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition continues to embed Artificial Intelligence (AI) at the core of business processes, enabling organizations to work smarter, faster, and with greater confidence. This release brings new AI-assisted capabilities across finance, service, and user experience, empowering employees to make data-driven decisions, reduce manual effort, and focus on higher-value tasks. By combining embedded AI, generative AI, and SAP’s digital assistant Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 sets a new benchmark for intelligent ERP — helping businesses unlock efficiency, innovation, and resilience in the cloud.

 1. Joule Copilots

1.1. Joule for Business

In today's fast-moving digital landscape, businesses need solutions that simplify processes and enhance efficiency. SAP’s Joule for Business stands at the forefront of this transformation. By embedding artificial intelligence directly into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Joule for Business acts as a digital assistant that helps users navigate complex tasks through natural language interaction. With its intuitive design and AI-driven functionality, Joule is not just an assistant—it’s a strategic partner for every business user.

Simplifying Service Contract Management with Joule for Business

For Customer Service Managers, Joule for Business is a game-changer. It allows managers to express their business needs using everyday language, eliminating the need for specialized technical knowledge. Joule then guides users directly to key service management applications, such as the Manage Service Contracts app, Service Management Overview, and Service Contracts Dashboard. The result? Users experience faster navigation, enhanced satisfaction, and improved operational efficiency. By providing seamless access to apps like Mass Processing of Service Contracts and Monitor Auto Renewal Logs, Joule ensures that service contract management becomes a streamlined and user-friendly process.

entry.title: Using SAP CALM Features App to Track Transports in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently I was exploring the capabilities of the SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) and their applications to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and found out we can use the Features app to track or document changes through transports.  This blog intends to use a video recording to showcase this new capability working in tandem.

 

Background

During the implementation of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we can create a project to guide us through the entire process, especially we can import the SAP Activate content to follow through. This project can be a big new implementation taking months to complete, or just adding a new feature from SAP’s latest innovation to be achieved in a few days.

For each project, we will associate with the cloud tenants.  For example, I define a 3 System Landscape in the below picture:

  • Development Tenant: Dev-100, Dev-080
  • Quality Assurance: TST-100
  • Production: PRD-100

Define a System Group with Relevant Systems in the CALM

 

After a project and its associate Deployment Landscape is defined, we can use the Features app to document and track the changes.  You can find the Features app with a truck icon from the Implementation tab, in the "Design, Build, Test, Deploy" block.

 

Demo

This demo is executed on four tenants: Dev-100, TST-100, PRD-100 and CALM. To get the point across, I create a simple user defined Business Role and add it to a dedicated Software Collection to export.  This export creates a transport to be imported to TST-100 and PRD-100.

In the first half of the demo, we go through all the steps without involvement of the CALM.  In the second half of the demo, from importing the transport to the TST-100, I start using the Features app of the CALM.

The demo is recorded and listed in the Reference section. Here is the recording timestamps and their corresponding steps.

 

Time StampDemo Content

00:06:00 – 02:42:07

In DEV-100 Tenant

entry.title: Inflation Accounting in Türkiye – Index-Based Asset Revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP now supports a significant legal requirement in Türkiye: index-based asset revaluation. (Inflation Accounting).

This regulation, mandated by Turkish tax and commercial law, requires companies to revalue their fixed assets based on monthly inflation indices published by the Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK).
This blog provides an overview of the legal requirement and explains how to meet it by demonstrating the implementation steps for a sample scenario.

About Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Türkiye

Index-based asset revaluation is a legal requirement in Türkiye introduced under the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the Official Gazette (issue 32415, 30.12.2023).
This regulation requires companies to adjust their financial statements based on producer price indices published by TÜİK (Turkish Statistical Institute).

The calculation of the adjustment coefficient is defined in Article 17 of the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the official Gazette (Resmi Gazete, issue 32415, 30.12.2023):

  • Five decimal places must be considered in the calculation.
  • The fifth digit must be rounded based on the sixth digit.

The official index values can be found here.

Note: Each customer is responsible for ensuring that the maintained index values and resulting calculations (including rounding) comply with the legal requirements!

 

Implementation Guide

This section explains the implementation steps of index-based revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for a sample scenario involving a simple asset. It lists the steps required to complete the set-up, posting, valuation checks, a partial retirement, and (optionally) a reversal.

Note:

  • The revaluation is not carried out in a separate depreciation area, but within the valuation view where the index is assigned (e.g. 1 = Book Depreciation, 15 = Local Tax).
  • Customers should not use the scope item for additional depreciation areas for this purpose, as adding extra areas does not support the revaluation process and will not provide the intended outcome.

Scenario Details

  • Asset APC: 12,000 TRY
  • Useful life: 10 years (120 periods)
  • Valuation view: The view where the index is assigned (e.g., 1 = Book Depreciation or 15 = Local Tax)
  • Revaluation index: Monthly index (assigned before acquisition)
  • Scenario extension: Partial retirement of 70% on 01 Mach 2025; optional reversal of postings

Prerequisites

Maintain G/L account determination for revaluation in the Assign G/L Accounts (ID: 102622) configuration activity.

Step-by-Step Procedure

  1. Create revaluation index
    1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app and create a new index with the following details:
      1. Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (e.g. INF_TR)
      2. Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly
      3. Unit of Measure: Index Points
    2. Maintain the monthly index values published by TÜİK: TÜIK Inflation and Price Statistics

    3. Activate the revaluation index by clicking on "Activate" to make it available for valuation views.

       

  2. Maintain asset master data
    1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.
    2. Create a new asset and maintain all mandatory values (cost centre, profit centre, segment) and other values relevant to your business.
    3. Under Valuation → General Parameters, assign the revaluation index created in step 1.


    4. Adjust the useful life (in years) if necessary, for example, 10 years.
    5. Apply changes and save.

  3. Post acquisition of the asset
    1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Acquisition → Acquisition (Net).

       

    2. In the new window, specify values for the following mandatory fields:
      1.          Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date
      2.          Amount Posted in Transaction Currency (12,000 TRY in our example)
      3.          Year of Acquisition (Prior Year in our example)
    3. Choose Simulate to check the postings and then choose Post.

  4. View depreciation amounts
    1. In the Managed Fixed Assets app, go to Valuation to review the effects of revaluation.
    2. Under Value Display → Depreciation, you will see both the regular depreciation and the additional revaluation amounts

      Fiscal Year 2024:

      Fiscal Year 2025:

Scenario Extension: The asset was acquired in July 2024 for 12,000 TRY. In March 2025, 70% of the asset needs to be retired.

  1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Retirement → Retirement without Revenue.


  2. Adjust the mandatory fields:
    • Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date to 01.03.2025
    • Retirement Type: Partial Retirement by Percentage Rate
    • Retirement Percentage: 70 %
    • Year of Acquisition: Prior Year

    • Choose Post.
    • The results can be viewed under Valuation.

Option: Reverse a posting, if required:

  1. Open the Reverse Journal Entries – In Asset Accounting app.
  2. Select the journal entry.
  3. Specify the mandatory values.
  4. Choose Reverse.

     

Annual Index Maintenance for 2025

According to the 582nd Sequence of the Tax Procedure Law (Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği, Sıra No: 582, published 15.02.2025), inflation accounting will not be applied for the first, second, and third provisional tax periods of 2025 (except for certain exempt taxpayers such as jewelers).
This change means that for 2025, the adjustment will only be performed once at the end of the year (31.12.2025).

Source: TÜRMOB – 2025 Yılı Geçici Vergi Dönemlerinde Enflasyon Düzeltmesi Yapılmayacak 

Following the legal change in February 2025, inflation accounting in Türkiye is now applied annually, not monthly or quarterly.
For 2025, the calculation will be based on the difference between the index value as of 31.12.2024 and the index value as of 31.12.2025.

Since no interim calculation is legally required, companies may enter “0” for the index values from January to November and enter the actual year-end value only in December.

This ensures that the adjustment is calculated exclusively at year-end, as required by law.

Disclaimer: This approach is based on current interpretations. Customers are responsible for verifying its legal validity for their specific case and ensuring compliance from both a regulatory and audit perspective.

 

Automated Index Maintenance via API

Instead of manually maintaining index values in the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, you can automate the process using the API API_ASSETREVALUATIONINDEX.
The API allows you to manage both the index header (ID, type, country/currency, unit of measure) and the monthly values (Valid From, Valid To, Index Value) programmatically.

 

Use Case
For example, companies can implement an SAP BTP integration or a partner app that retrieves official TÜİK data each month, validates it, and automatically writes it to their SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system. This removes the need for manual entry and ensures consistent, repeatable index maintenance.

Further Information: API Documentation on SAP Help Portal 

Automated Calculation via BadI

The BAdI FAA_DC_UPA_CUSTOMER with the method SET_PERCENT_VALUE can be used to define formulas for calculating percentage changes automatically.

Example:

Adjustment Coefficient = ((Index value current month / Index value previous month) – 1) * 100

Important: While both SET_PERCENT_VALUE and SET_BASE_VALUE methods are available as of 508, there is a known limitation when using them in scenarios with Periodic Revaluation and Depreciation Split.
In such scenarios, customers should not use the BAdI until this gap is resolved.

Further Information: Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects 

Support

If you’d like to use the new index type in Türkiye, please create a support incident using the component FI-LOC-FI-TR. To use the feature for other supported countries, use the relevant components.

For more information, refer to the documentation on SAP Help Portal: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index  and Index Type "Replacement Value, Monthly".

Conclusion

The new functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 allows Turkish companies to comply with the legal requirements for inflation accounting and index-based revaluation of assets.

Users can now effortlessly access their favorite apps and folders from anywhere within the platform, enhancing efficiency. Recap feature on My Home

With a focus on saving time, this intelligent feature highlights the changes since the user’s last login by comparing current data with the past 24 hours. It brings tasks needing attention right to the forefront, streamlining decision-making and increasing productivity by allowing users more time for strategic work.
